title: I Went to This
name: I Went to This
description:
A Map by Tracy_the_astonishing

Map of stuff I went to and how it was

properties.name: Annalee Newitz and Charlie Anders Reading
properties.description: Posted by Tracy_the_astonishing  7 Temple St., Cambridge, MAI hadn\'t been getting out to do interesting things about town for a while, so I was a little bit giddy about actually leaving home after dark, skipping the family meal, and going to a reading. I went to this event with my friend Justine, who is a neurobiologist. (I\'m just saying that to establish our geek cred. It doesn\'t have much to do with anything, really.) I was surprised when I got to the venue to discover that the Center for New Words was holding the reading in a tiny room of the YWCA in Central Square. The room was way too small. I had to sit on the floor under the podium, which I actually didn\'t mind at all. I really was just plain surprised. I hope that they manage to make some kind of arrangements with some of the local book stores around town for the future. Charlie\'s essay was great. It was all about discovering herself as a geeky policy wonk at the same time as she discovered herself as a woman (Charlie is transexual). It was funny and very well written. She seemed nervous, but who wouldn\'t be. She had on some adorable sequined Mary Janes. I thought I had gotten a picture of them, but I guess not. Nina Simone Dudnick read her essay "Sex and the Single (Woman) Biologist." She was a good reader. The essay was part about sexism in the Harvard Medical School and part about how men won\'t go out with scientists, which is ironically quite sexist. Justine and I spent some time over a plate of nachos after the show talking about this. Being smart has never prevented me from getting laid. Granted, I\'m not a scientist. But Justine is, and she has had no shortage of male admirers, and even three marriage proposals. Justine was sort of bristling about this essay after the reading. The sexist idea that men don\'t want to be with smart women really irked her, mostly because she has never found it to be true. I have to say that I concur. There are some irredeamable, emotionally retarded, insecure, sexist douche bags out there, but who wants to go out with them anyway? These are the guys who moulder in cranky bachelorhood and are generally more to be pitied than to be reviled. For the most part, the boys are all right. About the power structure in Harvard Medical School being sexist I don\'t doubt it, and the part of her essay which dealt with that was very interesting. Diana Husmann, an undergraduate student at MIT read her essay, "The Dress," all about being a girly-outdoorsy geeky girl. Annalee Newitz read last, excerpts from her essay, "When Diana Prince Takes off her Glasses." I\'m a fan of Newitz, which is the reason I dragged myself out of the house to go to the reading. I\'m looking forward to reading the whole essay. It\'s about role models and mentoring for young women and the insidious ways in which sexism can make you paranoid, among other things. Annalee ended her reading with the words "we rule," which caused a sort of comic quiproquo during the qa. The first question came from a woman who was not a native English speaker and she asked, "If you rule, what are you fighting about?" While the question came partly from a misunderstanding of American idioms, it is true that there are a lot of women I know who think that the fight against sexism is over, and that we won. It\'s important to appreciate what our mothers and grandmothers did to get where we are today, but it\'s also a mistake to think that sexism is a thing of the past. Sexism also is not a male-only problem. It\'s incredibly complicated. Another thing Justine and I talked about was the way a sexist attitude becomes so ingrained in young women that they adopt the kinds of postures toward other women that they\'ll eventually be be fighting themselves. She and I were both tomboys growing up. Sort of honorary males, until puberty (and a little beyond). I always had a couple really wonderful female friends, but for the most part, I thought women were stupid. If there were men and women having a serious conversation, I would tend to tune out the women. Some time in my early 20s, I was cured of this misogyny but I feel a bit of shame about it still. This kind of internalized, subconcious sexism against ourselves is maybe the most wretched form I know. After the reading I thought a bit about my own female role models. Mother, older friends, relatives, fictional heroes, teachers. Some of my first female role models were three heavy metal girls who took me under their wing when I started high school. They may not seem like likely role models for me or even good role models, but that\'s not really true. These girls, who were 17 and 18 years old, were strong. They were powerful. They were rebellious, sexual, outspoken, funny, and confident. They were never ignored and they didn\'t take any shit. ****** Date: January 11, 2007 @ 7 PM What: Reading for She\'s Such A Geek: Women Write About Science, Technology & Other Nerdy Stuff, edited by Annalee Newitz and Charlie Anders (Seal Press 2007) Location: The Center for New Words, 7 Temple St., Cambridge, MA Admission: Free Co-editors Annalee Newitz and Charlie Anders will read from their new anthology, She\'s Such A Geek, and discuss the growing role of women in the sciences, fandom, gaming and other areas. Also reading will be contributors Nina Simone Dudnik and Diana Husmann. They\'ll have a question and answer session about the book.

properties.name: Br Cleve @ ZuZu July 1, 2007. 10PM
properties.description: Posted by Tracy_the_astonishing 472 Mass Ave, Cambridge, MAUpdate: Had a very nice time hanging out with Clever before his set. I didn\'t stay for the show because I was so sleepy, but I did pop over to the Green Street Lounge to visit Misty, who I hadn\'t seen in about a decade. She and I used to work together at the Lizard Lounge, which is also where I met Cleve. ************ I haven\'t seen Cleve in ages. Maybe we can have dinner together before the show.

properties.name: Free Circuit-Bending Workshop, April 15, 2007
properties.description: Posted by Tracy_the_astonishing195g Elm Street, Somerville, MA, United StatesCircuit Bending Workshop and Improv Jam Session!!! Tuesday, April 15th at 7:00 @ Willoughby and Baltic Jimmie P. Rodgers will lead the group in a fun & informative circuit bending workshop. Participants should be advised to bring their own electronic toy(s) in. He\'ll show participants a few basic ("quick") bends, and the first half of the workshop will be spent exploring and modding their own toys. During the second half, the group will be split up into teams (between 4-6) and compete against one another to see who has the best sounding group of instruments. The event should end in a jam session, and Share.tv will be on hand to lead the improvisation. So go grab an electronic toy, and drop in. You can be a circuit-bending star!!!

properties.name: Jan 27 Cinema Circus, 9:30 AM @ the Brattle
properties.description: Posted by Tracy_the_astonishing   40 Brattle St, Cambridge, MAI got the tickets and took Vigo out to the 9:30 show. The films were really wonderful. The first one was a film version of the popular book Harry the Dirty Dog. The next film was a great version of There Was an Old Lady Who Swallowed a Fly, which has been a favorite of mine for my whole life. I mean... what a punch line. "She died, of course." In this version the different creatures were chasing each other around and... well you had to be there. I can tell just trying to start describing it that I\'ll never be able to portray the sheer, unfettered comedy of it. My favorite film was called A Windy Day. It was basically an edited recording of two sisters playing pretend games with a beautiful simple animation drawn over it. Brilliant. Made me want to record Vigo and Rowan. I wonder it its ethical to record children without telling them about it. I think if I get their permission to use it for an art project it would be all right. The last movie was about a big pack of Labrador Retrievers living out in the hills somewhere. It showed puppies being born. Pretty amazing. Vigo has a wonderful time and afterward, we went to Algiers and he had a hot chocolate. It was wonderful being out just the two of us. He\'s such an interesting person, and we don\'t get the time always for him to talk to me and tell me what is going on with the rest of his life, especially at school. We had a long talk about "bad words." I find the idea of "bad words" very annoying. I also hate that he\'s being given the idea that anything at all having to do with bodies is taboo. At the same time I understand that it\'s annoying to be in a room of five-year-olds who are laughing hyterically about poop and farting. But a while back, Vigo told me that "penises are bad." That pretty much stopped me in my tracks. Gotta keep on top of that deprogramming! Get Tickets Cinema Circus: A Family Film Festival at 9:30, 11:30 CCAE and the Brattle are, once again, collaborating to offer alternatives to modern media for children of all ages. You and your family will revel in a carefully curated - and age appropriate - mix of live action, narrative, non-narrative, nature and animated films. Our host will be film-loving child psychiatrist Adele Pressman, who is also a mother of two. Escape the multiplex and see some great films you won\'t find anywhere else on the Brattle\'s big screen. Bring your kids, nieces, nephews, grandchildren, god-children, or the kids who live upstairs! Last year this event sold out, so buy your tickets well in advance. .00 Adults, Kids (under 2 free). Tickets available now at CCAE.org (link below). Sponsored by Henry Bear\'s Park Showing at 9:30 and 11:30 AM

properties.name: Listen Watch Make, 11 March 2007
properties.description: Posted by Tracy_the_astonishing   Tali and Kyle came for a visit and in their honor we had a little event at our house. Activities included: * the building of a giant yarn web in the back yard * Chalk shadow tracing and drawing in the driveway * Drum set by Jesse * Video drawing with My First Sony and a projector * Custom t-shirt printing with stencils * All-ages jam session with Greg Kelly * After-party performance of Coat of Embrace by Lovid

properties.name: LoVid Performace at the MoMA, May 19, 2008 at 7PM
properties.description: Posted by Tracy_the_astonishing11 West 53 Street, New York, NY 10019-5497fun! LoVid: Wire-full LoVid is the New York–based interdisciplinary artist duo Tali Hinkis and Kyle Lapidus. Their work includes live video installations, sculptures, digital prints, patchworks, media projects, performances, and video recordings. They combine many opposing elements, contrasting hard electronics and soft patchworks; handmade items and machine-produced objects; and analog and digital. This multidirectional approach is reflected in the content of their work, simultaneously romantic and aggressive, wireless and wire-full. The artists present their performance Help Carry a Tune (2007) and perform with their Sync Armonica synthesizer. Program 90 min. Theater 2 (The Roy and Niuta Titus Theater 2), T2

properties.name: MIAO XIAOCHUN: MICROCOSM, gallery opening
properties.description: Posted by Tracy_the_astonishing Sophienstraße 21 10178 Berlin GermanySeptember 20th - October 25th 2008 Opening: September 19th, 7 - 9 pm The artist will be present. Miao Xiaochun creates by use of photography and modern computer animation programs montages of European masterpieces in virtual reality, as for example "The Garden of Delight" by Hieronymus Bosch. He replaces all human figures of the original painting with a digitalized image of himself. The results are large-sized paraphrases, captivating through visual splendor and an irritating discrepancy regarding the historical paragon. By taking over the role of all figures in the original painting, Miao is provoking a crucial question concerning the christian devouted concept of culture: Who am I, when I unite all characters in mine, good and bad? He replaces the separation into heaven and hell, unknown to Asian spiritual identity, with Yin and Yang, which complement and require each other. Hereby the original meaning is modified into a classical chinese image of a harmonious entity.

properties.name: Matthew Barney Performance. April 15, 2007.
properties.description: Posted by Tracy_the_astonishing440 44th Drive, Queens, NYtracyrolling: Vigo and I went to see a live Matthew Barney performance last night. Bjork was there. it was good aaronolmstead: bjork was there tracyrolling: yeah. she\'s cute. it was a good show. there was a bull in it aaronolmstead: wow tracyrolling: unfortunately something is up with my zone tag so the pictures aren\'t there yet. they\'re not going to be good. It was dark in the giant warehouse on the waterfront. I hadn\'t seen any of Barney\'s stuff in a whil. Looks like he\'s obsessed with Chrysler and ancient mythologies and human sacrifice displaced half a step. He was wearing an outfit that included a very cute little dog sitting on his head (Egyptian). And he pulled parts of an old wreck of a car and held them up to the audience more Mayan). He put the car organs into urns. The music was great I didn\'t get to see what was up with the bul. There was a mount for collected bull semen sticking out of the back of the car (homemade but recognizable) but we were on the other side aaronolmstead: how does one recognize a mount for collected bull semen? tracyrolling: I didn\'t recognize it at first but they put a cow skin over it and I put two and two together aaronolmstead: I see. And you have pictures of this all, you say? tracyrolling: pictures aren\'t showing up yet

properties.name: Museum of Science Friday Nights
properties.description: Posted by Tracy_the_astonishing  Exhibit Halls are open until 9:00 p.m.! Start with a martini and an appetizer at the Sci ence Street Café, then follow that up with an Omni film and free stargazing at the Gilliland Observatory (weather permitting). Don\'t forget, on the first Friday of every month from September to May, we bring you some of the most exciting speakers in New England as part of our First Friday lectures series. Equipped with a computer-controlled, 12-inch Meade LX200 telescope and staffed by knowledgeable Museum employees, the Gilliland Observatory is the perfect way to end a Friday evening at the Museum. Weather permitting, the observatory is open every Friday, 8:30-10 p.m. Tucked away on the roof of the Museum\'s parking garage, this is a wonderful resource for our starry-eyed public. Prepare for your observatory viewing by attending the Museum\'s Friday night showing of The Sky Tonight at 7:00 p.m. in the Charles Hayden Planetarium. Admittance is free; please call the Gilliland Observatory Hotline, 617-589-0267, which is updated at 5:30 p.m. on Friday nights with information about that night\'s observing session. The hotline also lists general information about the observatory, what objects can be observed in the current night sky, and how to contact an observatory staff person.

properties.name: Object of Desire. April 20, 2007.
properties.description: Posted by Tracy_the_astonishing475 10th Ave New York, NYArtist’s Talk with Yael Kanarek, 7:15 PM Panel Discussion, 8:00 PM Exit Art, bitforms gallery and Renew Media are pleased to announce the world premiere of Internet artwork Object of Desire by Yael Kanarek, taking place Friday April 20 at Exit Art. The evening will begin with a talk by the artist at 7:15 PM and follow with a panel discussion. Object of Desire is the third chapter in World of Awe, and online travelogue (www.worldofawe.net) that chronicles a search for lost treasure in a parallel world called Sunset/Sunrise. The project imagines a post-gender and post-national protagonist. Born from an observation that language defines borders and territory on the Internet, Object of Desire examines these borders, as the chapter is written in three languages: English, Arabic and Hebrew. Challenging the notion of fixed territory, thirteen scenes of the online project download from servers in four locations-—in Ramallah, Tel Aviv, Izmir and New York. Object of Desire has four web addresses by which to enter: New York: http://www.eyebeam.org/objectofdesire Tel Aviv: http://digitalartlab.org.il/objectofdesire Ramallah: http://www.donialrahba.ps Izmir: http://www.nomad-objectofdesire.net During the artist’s talk, Yael will guide the audience through several scenes, point to memes born in the Middle East and Mediterranean that are present in contemporary culture, and describe how three geographies—physical, virtual and fictional—overlap in this project. For the panel, Yael invited colleagues to consider how the Internet enables the emergent of a post-national identity alongside burgeoning nationalism and the strengthening of nation-states by globalization. The evening will conclude with a Q&A.

properties.name: Oct 27, 2007. 10AM-4PM. Play Date: From Ordinary to Extraordinary @ the ICA
properties.description: Posted by Tracy_the_astonishingOctober 27, 2007 Saturday , 10:00 AM to 04:00 PM Pins, burnt wood, and rubber bands! Find out how artists turn ordinary materials into remarkable works of art. Then come to the Bank of America Art Lab to do some transforming of your own. At 11:30 am and 2 pm The Mystic Beast transforms with more than 50 masks in the show “Art Fool.” This program and museum admission are free for 2 adults per family with children 12 and under. No prior registration is necessary, but theater events are ticketed. Tickets are free and available first-come, first-served at the admissions desk on the day of the program. This Play Date is sponsored by Sarah and Peter Monaco.

properties.name: October 5-7, 2007. Honkfest
properties.description: Posted by Tracy_the_astonishingDavis Square, Somerville, MAAcross the country and around the world, a new type of street band is emerging. Acoustic and mobile, borrowing repertoire and inspiration from a diverse set of folk music traditions – New Orleans second line brass bands, European Klezmer, Balkan and Gypsy music, Brazilian Afro Bloc and Frevo traditions, as well as the passion and spirit of Mardi Gras and Carnivale – these “honkers” all share a commitment to several core principles. Metaphorically speaking, they honk their horns for the same reasons motorists honk theirs: to arouse fellow travelers, to warn of danger, to celebrate milestones, and to just plain have fun.

properties.name: Psyforia Festival August 4, 2007. 2PM-1AM
properties.description: Posted by Tracy_the_astonishing This was so fun. I wish we had brought Vigo. I talked to a lot of people and really enjoyed myself. 18+ , 0 suggested Donation Free food will be served! -Lineup- In order of appearance: -Ammon EP- (Sonic Beating/Soul Trance Records) !!Special Afternoon Birhday Brunch Set!! Join us at 2PM for the official kickoff to the hottest party of the summer. Those who get there early will be treated to a free pancake brunch care of Sonic Beating. -MISS FAIRCHILD- (Nantucketastrophie Records,JiveSucka) For those of who who haven\'t been exposed to the Nu-Funk/Soul sensation that is MF, prepare to have your world rocked. Be warned, you will dance uncontrollably check them out at www.Missfairchild.com -TONY UNORTHODOX- (28th Day ? New York) 28th Day\'s premier DJ, Tony will be continuing the precedence of deep funk with his unique blend of electro house and smooth deep trance. -KARMAKANIK- (Gaian Mind/PSI - Philadelphia) known far and wide as one of the best progressive psy DJs in Philly, Pat will be escalating the vibe of the party to new heights with signature selection of smooth yet driving beats. - 3 Hour Sonic Beating Tag Team Extravaganza - Sit back and enjoy as the home team takes the field. We\'ll be weaving a tapestry of psychedelia from progressive to full on. The combined forces of Dave Henshaw, Dave Dittmer, Ammon EP, Bob Trahpek, Fred Owsley and Nick Binary will assemble to form the unstoppable dance floor juggernaut Aka the Sonic Beating residents. -FRACTAL PHONO- (Gaian Mind/Goa Home-Philadelphia) Be sure not to miss the commencement of the evening as Fractal phono takes control and proceeds to slay the dance floor his choice selection of psy. First Boston Appearance! EG~BOT (Gaian Mind/PSI - Philadelphia) The party goes into overdrive as EG-BOT takes the DJ booth. This master of the night sound will have the dancefloor worked into a frenzy in no time. Mathwin (Synesthetic - Boston) Long time resident of the Boston psy scene who has just returned from the west coast. Mathwin has been known for many years to play only the finest full on psy around. This marks his first showing since returning to Boston from SF. Prepare for to have your mind blown. RAFAEL ZANETTI (Sao Paulo, Brazil/NH) Quickly becoming one of the most sought after full on DJs on the east coast, Rafael\'s sets have become the thing of legend within the psy community. Impeccable track selection, flawless mixing skills plus a style and energy all his own. We\'re honored to have him close out the party.

properties.name: STREB v Gravity, Feb 25. 2PM
properties.description: Posted by Tracy_the_astonishing   100 Northern Avenue Boston, MAUpdate: The dancing was impressive, but the staging could have been a lot better. I heard rumor that the evening shows had a lot more lighting effects. Too bad. It was really a lot of fun. They have a great sense of humor. We had to leave our weekend out in the wilds of Western Mass a bit early to get to the show, but it was worth it. Vigo loved it. Intertwining the disciplines of dance, extreme sports, and Hollywood stunt work, Elizabeth Streb has created a vocabulary that combines strict precision and daring in a display of “pure movement.” In her new show, "STREB vs. Gravity," Streb’s human movement maestros explore the boundaries of force, gravity, action, and reaction. Whether flying, falling, or seemingly suspended in mid-air, the company fearlessly challenges nature, creating a new aesthetic of grace and danger. Tickets go on sale January 16. RELATED EVENT: Elizabeth Streb, founder and artistic director of STREB talks about the physics of dance at the Museum of Science. For more information, call 617-723-2500 or log onto www.mos.org/art

properties.name: Sat Nov 11, starting at 5 PM. Rollerderby
properties.description: Posted by Tracy_the_astonishing Wilmington, MADon\'t miss this rematch of the March playoff bout that put the Pissahs on track toward the Season One championship and sent the Nutcrackers back to the drawing board to hone their strategies for Season Two. Have the Pissahs been resting on their laurels all summer or will they come out swinging? What have the Nuts been preparing in their break from the spotlight, and will it be enough to rattle the ladies in red? Musical guests The Great Bandini inject high-energy power pop into two minisets, and DJ Boo Boo Danger keeps the beats flowing through the on-site after party in the Fez Room. Tickets for this bout are only 4 in advance

properties.name: Saturday Dec 8, 2007. Rollerderby. Nutcrackers vs. Cosmonaughties

properties.name: Sept 10 (Monday) 6-8 PM. Davis Square Block Party @ Redbones
properties.description: Posted by Tracy_the_astonishing Davis Square, Somerville, MADavis Square residents and all who love Davis Square are invited to the first ever DARBI Mega Block Party which be held on Monday, September 10 from 6-8 pm at Redbones, 55 Chester Street, Somerville, MA. A buffet dinner, designed to satisfy both carnivores and vegetarians, is for DARBI members and 0 for non-members. A DARBI resident membership is 0 for the year and includes a free t-shirt (a 5 value). Membership is open to anyone who lives in or loves Davis Square. Non-members will have an opportunity to join at the event and enjoy a fun evening and a fabulous Redbones meal for . The event will also include a number of door prizes, courtesy of Davis Square businesses, and a cash bar. All proceeds from the event will support the HONK! Festival\'s return to Davis Square on October 5th. (www.honkfest.org). HONK! Is a grassroots festival of activist street bands from all over the U.S. and beyond, playing music that celebrates progressive ideals. Redbones, famous for its authentic down home-style Southern food and unique ambience, is located in the heart of Davis Square.

We dressed up in our grass skirts and went out to Union Square shouting "Aloha" to everyone we passed on the way. Vigo danced his heart out and Rowan fell in love with the hula dancers. Thank you Somerville Arts Council! (rain date: Saturday) Enjoy the exotic sounds of Waitiki and The Mai Tai Serenaders, DJ\'ing by Brother Cleve, hula dancers and Polynesian dance arts, vintage films of Hawaii and Polynesia, and other special events!

properties.name: Sept 21, 2007. 8PM. Experiment featuring DJ Scientific @ the ICA
properties.description: Posted by Tracy_the_astonishing100 Northern Avenue Boston, MAUpdate Sept 12 I got tickets for Erik, Vigo, and myself. **** September 21, 2007 Friday , 08:00 PM Tickets: 5 general admission; 0 members Mix together bold contemporary art, house-shaking beats, and food and drink from Wolfgang Puck. While Hearthrob starts off the night, visit a multimedia lounge. Later on, the party heats up as DJ Scientific spins. Must be 21 years of age. Tickets go on sale to Associate level members and above on August 16, general public September 1.

properties.name: Sept 22, 2007. 5 PM. Rollerderby @ Shriners Auditorium
properties.description: Posted by Tracy_the_astonishing 99 Fordham Rd Wilmington, MA 01887Boston Massacre vs. Virginia\'s Dominion Derby Girls Doors at 5 pm, Bout at 6 pm Shriners Auditorium, Wilmington, MA Tickets 4 in advance, 6 at the door Half time entertainment by Can\'t Face the Falling Public after party on site with DJ Boo Boo Danger Boston Derby Dames\' second season kicks off with an all-star bout between the Massacre and the visiting Dominion Derby Girls All-Stars. The Massacre have fared well against opponents from below the Mason-Dixon line, with home track wins against Baltimore\'s Charm City Rollergirls in April and Atlanta\'s All Stars in June. Will the Dominion Derby Girls All-Stars be able to prove that Virginia isn\'t just for lovers, or will Boston\'s quad-skate militia once again bring the beatdown on their nemesisters from the south? Providence\'s emo-influenced rockers, the all-female Can\'t Face the Falling, play two minisets during period breaks. Fans of Cursive and Death Cab for Cutie take note, and check out their tunes on MySpace. And, as always, everyone is invited to the on-site Fez Room for an after party with DJ Boo Boo Danger.

properties.name: Sept 23, 2007. Riversing
properties.description: Posted by Tracy_the_astonishing  DeWolf St. & Memorial DriveJoin Revels and the Charles River Conservancy for a free community sing celebrating the first day of fall! From atop the Weeks Bridge linking Boston and Cambridge, and bathed in light, on Sunday, September 23rd, Revels music director George Emlen (and giant puppets Oshun and Poseidon) will lead everyone gathered along the banks of the Charles in river songs and songs of the season. The 4th annual RiverSing will be a festive musical affair. Joining us on the bridge this year will be members of be Nick Page’s Mystic Chorale, Revels Circle of Song, the Halalisa Singers and other Boston area choruses, all accompanied by keyboard, guitar, bass and drums. In addition, local saxophone greats Stan Strickland, fresh off his award-winning one-man show, and Ken Field of The Revolutionary Snake Ensemble, will play antiphonally across the Charles with a third sax, played by Chris O’Brien, joining in as well. The public is invited bring a bell to ring in the new season (we’ll ring our 40-pound River Bell) and join the many singers, musicians and friends of the parklands in this exciting fall tradition that literally links Boston and Cambridge in song! Picnics are encouraged! Come early and spread your blanket on the grass or meet us at Winthrop Park in Harvard Square at 5:00 pm where select area restaurants will be handing out pre-ordered picnic meals. Then join us for a 5:45 pm processional down to the Charles led by larger-than-life puppets created by the Puppet Collaborative, and local jazz legends the New Orleans-style Second Line Social Aid and Pleasure Society Brass Band.

properties.name: Sept 25-27, 21007. Emerging Tech Conference @ MIT
properties.description: Posted by Tracy_the_astonishing48 Massachusetts Ave, Cambridge, Massachusetts 02139

properties.name: Sept 29 (Saturday) 2007, 4-7 PM. What the Fluff
properties.description: Posted by Tracy_the_astonishing 4-7pm (rain date Sept. 30) Union Square Plaza It’s the 90th anniversary of Fluff, invented by the culinary genius Archibald Query, right here in Union Square. This year, ArtsUnion will once again pay homage to this yummy, sticky, sweet American spreadable treat. Artists, musical and theatrical performers, humorists and the general public will indulge in a madcap festival that celebrates the culinary invention and nostalgic genius of FLUFF.

properties.name: Tali and Kyle's opening March 12, 2007.  6:30 PM
properties.description: Posted by Tracy_the_astonishing   update: Tali and Kyle gave a couple of lectures at Mass Art this week and on Tuesday night, the students set up a little event for them. The students all built little structures in the Student Life Gallery Space. They made vegan cookies shaped like video feedback from stencils Tali made. The kids especially had a great time. After the show, we all went out for dinner. Tuesday March 12, 2007 at 6:30 PM LOVID

properties.name: Trans Am Opening--almost made it
properties.description: Posted by Tracy_the_astonishing   61 Washington Park, Newtonville , MA 02460I tried to go to this, but I got completely lost. I drove from my house to Harvard Square via Belmont. I have no sense of direction. Most of the time I was driving I had *no idea* where I was. At one point I screamed an incredibly long, roaring, throat-rending scream in the car which kind of frightened me. I almost cried. "Why no map?" you must be wondering. Well, you see, it\'s like this. The printer is in the "office" which is still filled with boxes we haven\'t unpacked yet, and the light bulb in the "office" is burned out. I wanted to go up and print out a map, but I was afraid of the dark. Yes, afraid of the dark. So I wrote down the directions, looked intently at the map for a while, and went off on my way to loserdom. The up side is that I found a miraculous parking space in Harvard Square. Unheard of on a Friday night. If I had had to go back home defeated because I couldn\'t find a parking space, I really would have been sad. That actually happened to me once, in Boston. The friends I was supposed to meet at the show came to the square and we had a nice dinner together. January 18 – March 4, 2007 Opening Reception: Friday, January 26, 6-8pm Gallery Talk: Sunday, February 4, 2pm ATTENTION: Please consider yourself invited to TRANS AM, a three person show of paintings at the New Art Center in Newton, MA, featuring ** Jason Chase **, ** Will DiBello **, and ** Scott Listfeld **. Between the three of them, Chase, DiBello, and Listfield are three of the most exciting young painters in all of New England, according to people who know them at least pretty well. The show is also curated by Scott Listfield, making this the first show he has curated in all of Newton. Did I mention there will be Hot Wheels cars at the opening? There will be, along with 50 feet of track. There will also be over 30 paintings in many colors, for instance: orange. And also blue. Please come to the show, I promise you will not regret it. Sincerely, Jason Chase, Will DiBello and Scott Listfield T: (617) 964-3424

properties.name: Until March 2008. Bourgeois in Boston @the ICA
properties.description: Posted by Tracy_the_astonishing100 Northern Ave., Boston, MA, United StatesIn the sixty years since her first solo exhibition, Louise Bourgeois has become one of our most influential living artists. Her emotionally-charged body of work, a distinctive mix of abstraction and figuration, delves into childhood memories and the struggles of everyday life. Utilizing a variety of materials—wood, bronze, marble, steel, rubber, and fabric—she crafts highly symbolic and personally cathartic objects that reference the body, sexuality, family, trauma, and anxiety. "All my work…all my subjects, have found their inspiration in my childhood. My childhood has never lost its magic, it has never lost its mystery, and it has never lost its drama." – Louise Bourgeois Among the works in the exhibition are a rare, early painting and more than 25 works on paper, which will be rotated over the course of the exhibition (new groupings will be presented on May 22, August 28, and November 26). The selection of sculptures spans the entirety of her career and ranges from a hand-stitched figure made with the artist\'s old clothing to Spider (1996), a spindly bronze arachnid that looms more than 10 feet tall. The breadth of work in Boston allows us to chart Bourgeois\'s artistic shifts, as well as make links between themes that have long consumed her.

properties.name: Visual Music Marathon, April 28, 2007.
properties.description: Posted by Tracy_the_astonishing  120 Forsyth Street, Boston, MA 02115Full Schedule and awesome preview video Over 300 works from 33 countries were submitted to the Marathon. Of these, 64, representing 6 hours of programming, were selected for screening. The remaining six hours will be devoted to invited artists, historic works on 16mm film, works provided by two guest curators, and approximately one hour of live video performance art. HOUR 1 (10 am - 11 am) HOUR 2 (11 am - 12 pm) HOUR 3: HISTORIC WORKS (12 pm - 1 pm ) HOUR 4: BEST OF THE IOTA CENTER (1 pm - 2 pm ) HOUR 5 (2 pm - 3 pm) HOUR 6 (3 pm - 4 pm ) HOUR 7 (4 pm - 5 pm ) HOUR 8: BEST OF THE DIGITAL SALON AND SVA (5 pm - 6 pm) HOUR 9 (6 pm - 7 pm) HOUR 10: LIVE VIDEO PERFORMANCES (7 pm - 8 pm) HOUR 11 (8 pm - 9 pm) HOUR 12 (9 pm - 10 pm)

properties.name: Vivienne Westwood Opening at the de Young Museum
properties.description: Posted by Tracy_the_astonishing 50 Tea Garden Dr. San Francisco, CA, 94118Visiting San Francisco for the weekend, I joined some friends of mine there to go to the opening party of the Vivienne Westwood exhibit. I spent the entire time inside the show and by the time I got out, it was too late for me to get my free cocktail. The show is set up in on a chronologically linear path, which is not a particularly creative way to do things, but more pedagogical. I enjoyed that and thought it was not a bad decision on the part of the curator. The lighting was very, very low on the show. I wonder if there is more light in the daytime. It\'s a shame to dull the colors of her work in bad lighting. Walking through the show, I felt inspired, saw a lot of little ideas I\'d like to use, and then felt a bit depressed knowing that I haven\'t any time at all to make things these days. Or at least not as many things as I would like. It is a great feeling, though to turn on the designing lights in my brain for a couple hours and give the part of me that uses those ideas a bit of exercise. The crowd was very mellow and mostly dressed to the hilt. Lots of corsets, of course. If ever there was an opprotunity to haul out the corset, well, this was it. The person with the best get up was wearing a buffalo-head hat. There were a couple drag queens in pastel-colored victorian wigs who were pretty remarkable, also.

properties.name: ✓ Boredoms concert with Birgit and Sam July 7, 2007, 4pm
properties.description: Posted by Tracy_the_astonishing   Update: I went to this, but the line was so slow and long that I didn\'t want to wait in it with Vigo, so I took him down to the river to get ice cream. I missed my opprtunity to get in with Erik and Birgit and Sam, and took Vigo for a long walk down to the beach at the Brooklyn Bridge Park. The pool was closed due to infant feces (gross) but we had a nice time hanging out on the sand. When we came back, the show was still going on so we listened outside for a while and then went to get some sushi and wait for the rest of our gang. I think Vigo would have enjoyed the show and I\'m disappointed that I missed it. ********************* Celebrating their 20th anniversary, the legendary Japanese avant-garde rock band the Boredoms will debut 77 DRUM on 07/07/07 on the lawn of the Empire-Fulton Ferry State Park section of Brooklyn Bridge Park. The band will lead 77 drummers in a once-in-a-lifetime performance. 4pm until dusk. FREE! RSVP required: http://www.viceland.com/77boadrum/ Shannon Mayers 718-802-0603 x19 smayers@bbpc.net
